Package com.stuypulse.stuylib.control

Class Controller

java.lang.Object
com.stuypulse.stuylib.control.Controller
Direct Known Subclasses:
PIDCalculator, PIDController
public abstract class Controller
extends java.lang.Object
The controller class is an abstract class that is used to create different controllers. All a class will need to do is implement calculate(double error), and then the user would use the update() functions, which work as a sort of wrapper for the controllers. No matter what controller is used, these functions will always work. <<<<<<< HEAD These functions in the controller are useful for an error based system, and are automatically managed, making implementations of PID easy.
======= These functions in the controller are useful for an error based system, and are automatically managed, making implementations of PID easy.
>>>>>>> cee2d99de4addd2fc4793c4f899a30e81eba93c5

    Constructors 
    Modifier Constructor Description
    protected Controller()
    Creates a basic controller with everything initialized

  • Method Summary

    Modifier and Type Method Description
    protected abstract double calculate​(double error)
    Update the controller with the error just measured
    double getError()
    Gets the error from the last time that .update() was called
    double getOutput()
    Gets the motor output from the last time that .update() was called
    double getRate()
    Gets the rate of the controller during the last .update() command.
    double getRawVelocity()
    Gets the velocity, which is represented as the change in error since the last time that .update() was called
    double getVelocity()
    Gets the velocity from the last time that .update() was called adjusted to velocity per second
    boolean isDone​(double maxError)
    Get whether or not the Controller has arrived at the target.
    boolean isDone​(double maxError, double maxVelocity)
    Get whether or not the Controller has arrived at the target.
    Controller setErrorFilter​(IStreamFilter filter)
    Lets you specify a filter that will be applied to all measurements that are given to the controller.
    Controller setOutputFilter​(IStreamFilter filter)
    Lets you specify a filter that will be applied to all of the outputs of the controller.
    Controller setVelocityFilter​(IStreamFilter filter)
    Lets you specify a filter that will be applied to the velocity measurements.
    double update​(double error)
    Update the controller with the error from the destination that you want to reach
    double update​(double measurement, double setpoint)
    Update the controller with the measurement that was just made and the set point you would like it to approach This function just subtracts the two at this moment.

      setErrorFilter

      public final Controller setErrorFilter​(IStreamFilter filter)
      Lets you specify a filter that will be applied to all measurements that are given to the controller. =======

      setErrorFilter

      public final Controller setErrorFilter​(IStreamFilter filter)
      Lets you specify a filter that will be applied to all measurements that are given to the controller. >>>>>>> cee2d99de4addd2fc4793c4f899a30e81eba93c5 A highly recommended option is the LowPassFilter due to its ability to remove noise, and its ability to not lag behind when there has been a gap in calls. This will slightly degrade the performance of the controller, but it may be necessary sometimes in order to get consistent results. This will change the way the controller interacts with the robot and may require more tuning to be done. Passing in null will disable the filter.
      Parameters:
      filter - filter to be applied to error measurements
      Returns:
      reference to the controller (so you can chain the commands together)
    • <<<<<<< HEAD

      setVelocityFilter

      public final Controller setVelocityFilter​(IStreamFilter filter)
      Lets you specify a filter that will be applied to the velocity measurements. =======

      setVelocityFilter

      public final Controller setVelocityFilter​(IStreamFilter filter)
      Lets you specify a filter that will be applied to the velocity measurements. >>>>>>> cee2d99de4addd2fc4793c4f899a30e81eba93c5 This can be used to smooth out the otherwise noisy velocity values. This can negatively affect things like the D in PID if set too high and it is recommended that you just filter the error instead.
      Parameters:
      filter - filter to be applied to velocity measurements
      Returns:
      reference to the controller (so you can chain the commands together)
    • <<<<<<< HEAD

      setOutputFilter

      public final Controller setOutputFilter​(IStreamFilter filter)
      Lets you specify a filter that will be applied to all of the outputs of the controller. =======

      setOutputFilter

      public final Controller setOutputFilter​(IStreamFilter filter)
      Lets you specify a filter that will be applied to all of the outputs of the controller. >>>>>>> cee2d99de4addd2fc4793c4f899a30e81eba93c5 If the robot has a tendency to jerk, or motions of the robot are too violent, a filter like the LowPassFilter can reduce jerk while still letting the robot get to max speed. This will slightly degrade the performance of the controller, but it may be necessary sometimes in order to get consistent results. This will change the way the controller interacts with the robot and may require more tuning to be done. Passing in null will disable the filter.
      Parameters:
      filter - filter to be applied to the outputs of the controller
      Returns:
      reference to the controller (so you can chain the commands together)

      getRate

      public double getRate()
      Gets the rate of the controller during the last .update() command. This will only return the interval between the last .update() command and the one before it. Thus, the rate may be slightly inconsistent if the update command is not called regularly. =======

      getRate

      public double getRate()
      Gets the rate of the controller during the last .update() command. This will only return the interval between the last .update() command and the one before it. Thus, the rate may be slightly inconsistent if the update command is not called regularly. >>>>>>> cee2d99de4addd2fc4793c4f899a30e81eba93c5 This function may be overridden if a special controller needs a custom rate.
      Returns:
      the rate of the controller during the last .update() command
